p: Although the general principles of the SN approach are now well established (Brown & Wilby, 2012; Chiew, 2006; Prudhomme et al., 2010), there have been a limited number of practical applications in regional‐ to national‐scale management, particularly in data‐sparse jurisdictions (Kay, Crooks, Davies, Prudhomme, et al., 2014; Prudhomme, Crooks, et al., 2013). In a relatively data‐rich study Prudhomme, Crooks, et al. ( 2013) demonstrated the framework's utility for flood risk assessment using 154 UK catchments. Catchments were grouped into distinct sensitivity types and used to classify ungauged sites based on their shared physical attributes (Prudhomme, Kay, et al., 2013). Similarly, Köplin et al. ( 2012) clustered 186 Swiss catchments based on their sensitivity and used results to identify which physiographic features discriminate response type. In an exploratory study Bastola et al. ( 2012) examined flood sensitivity for four Irish catchments for which the risk of design allowances being exceeded were assessed using the IPCC AR4 climate scenarios. Wilby et al. ( 2014) applied a similar approach to assess sensitivity of peak flows in the Boyne catchment (Eastern Ireland).
